introduction.p: The series \sum \frac{1}{k^p} are special series called p-series. We have already seen that the p-series with p=1 (the harmonic series) diverges. We investigate the behavior of other p-series in this activity.

statement.p: Evaluate the improper integral \int_1^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^2} \ dx. Does the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^2} converge or diverge? Explain.

hint.p: Small hints for each of the prompts above.

solution.p: We evaluate the improper integral: \int_{1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^2} \ dx \amp = \lim_{t \to \infty} \int_{1}^{t} \frac{1}{x^2} \ dx\amp = \lim_{t \to \infty} -\frac{1}{x} \biggm|_{1}^{t}\amp = \lim_{t \to \infty} \left(-\frac{1}{t} + \frac{1}{1} \right)\amp = 1. So the improper integral converges. The Integral Test then shows that the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^2} converges.

statement.p: Evaluate the improper integral \int_1^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^p} \ dx where p \gt 1. For which values of p can we conclude that the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^p} converges?

solution.p:
Assume p \gt 1. Then p-1 \gt 0 and so x^{-p+1} = \frac{1}{x^{p-1}} and
\lim_{x \to \infty} x^{-p+1} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{x^{p-1}} = 0 . Thus, \int_{1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^p} \ dx \amp = \lim_{t \to \infty} \int_{1}^{t} \frac{1}{x^p} \ dx\amp = \lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{x^{-p+1}}{-p+1} \biggm|_{1}^{t}\amp = \frac{1}{1-p} \lim_{t \to \infty} \left(t^{-p+1} - 1 \right)\amp = \frac{1}{p-1}. So the improper integral \int_1^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^p} \ dx converges when p \gt 1. The Integral Test then shows that the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^p} converges when p \gt 1.

statement.p: Evaluate the improper integral \int_1^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^p} \ dx where p \lt 1. What does this tell us about the corresponding p-series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^p}?

solution.p:
Assume p \lt 1. Then 1-p \gt 0 and so
\lim_{x \to \infty} x^{-p+1} = \infty . Thus, \int_{1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^p} \ dx \amp = \lim_{t \to \infty} \int_{1}^{t} \frac{1}{x^p} \ dx\amp = \lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{x^{-p+1}}{-p+1} \biggm|_{1}^{t}\amp = \frac{1}{1-p} \lim_{t \to \infty} \left(t^{-p+1} - 1 \right)\amp = \infty. So the improper integral \int_1^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^p} \ dx diverges when p \lt 1. The Integral Test then shows that the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k^p} also diverges when p \lt 1.
